awd_titl_txt: New Finite Element Techniques for Simulating Flows and Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
Computer simulations of various natural and technological processes require accurate and efficient numerical approximation of flows and waves. This project advances the state of the art by developing unconventional approaches that improve numerical techniques at the heart of such simulations. In addition to the anticipated mathematical inventions, the project also plans to develop a public-domain open-source software product  implementing the new techniques and use the product to solve simulation problems in varied application domains including geological hazard mitigation and material science. Through inclusion of under-represented minorities, the project activities contribute to the foundation's goals to widen participation of all in science.

The technical work on the project is divided into two lines of inquiry. One leads to new methods for capturing wave solutions of hyperbolic systems, methods that are expected to excel on the emerging many-core architectures. Another line of inquiry leverages a new mathematical ingredient to obtain structure-preserving numerical approximations of viscous flows. The first line of inquiry is motivated by the observation that when hyperbolic solutions can be advanced in time by varying amounts at varying spatial locations, the allocation of computational resources is optimized. When this can also be done concurrently, much faster simulations are possible. New fast methods on unstructured spacetime meshes of causal spacetime tents are the projected outcome. The advances from this project benefit simulation of various wave propagation systems as well as inviscid compressible flows. Viscous incompressible flows are targeted by the second line of inquiry. Using a Sobolev space of matrix-valued functions, novel formulations are constructed that yield optimal fluid stress approximations, exact mass conservation, and pressure robustness. Work in both lines of inquiry involve answering several technical questions, shown to be fundamental, and of potential disciplinary impact beyond the confines of this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project produced new simulation techniques for computational modeling of processes with flow fields and wave propagation. These new techniques improve the state of the art through one of more of the following features: enhanced accuracy of numerical solutions, faithful preservation of certain practically important structures in the exact processes, or increased efficiency leading to quicker simulations.

In one of two main lines of work in project, new numerical methods for viscous incompressible fluid flows were developed, motivated by current challenges in accurate prediction of flow quantities like lift and drag. These methods yield accurate viscous stress approximations and an exactly mass conserving velocity approximation in addition topressure and vorticity approximations. To approximate viscous stresses, new tensor-valued finite elements with continuous shear components were developed. Rigorous mathematical guarantees were built by developing proofs of optimal convergencerates and pressure-robust error estimates.

In the second line of project work, general hyperbolic systems were targeted, encompassing varied wave phenomena, inviscid compressible flows, and transport. Considering an off the beaten track technique to stratify a spacetime simulation area by tent-shaped subregions, the project developed new ways to advance simulations in time progressively through unstructured spacetime fronts. The tents provide a natural and rational way to incorporate local time stepping, without losing high-order accuracy in space and time, and without any ad hoc projection or extrapolation steps.  Leveraging task parallelism, the novel explicit schemes for unstructured spacetime tent meshes realized significant efficiency gains on modern many-core computer architectures.

The majority of the products in this project take the form of publications in rigorously reviewed journals, all of which are available in the Public Access Repository of the foundation. Some products also take the form of open-source software, available in the public domain, complete with documentation, usage examples, and tutorials. All the results from this grant were disseminated in professional conferences andworkshops. One international workshop was organized locally.

 

Education and training were integrated into the grant activities.Training of two PhD students, two MS students, and two undergraduate students were incorporated into this grant's research activities.  The students supported include the first Native American graduate of the local doctoral program.  Undergraduate training resources, developed as lectures on mathematical computing, were disseminated through the local library as open-access educational material. External internships enhanced the research and educational experiences of the trainees.
